headline: Best Ever Irish Soda Bread
description: Make this moist Irish soda bread for your St. Patrick's Day dinner or anytime you'd like a nice hearty side dish to go with your meal. It has plenty of raisins.
name: Best Ever Irish Soda Bread

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C). Grease a 9-inch cake pan.

Stir together the flour, sugar, salt, baking powder, and baking soda in a large bowl. Using a pastry cutter, cut the butter gently into the flour mixture until well combined, and stir in the raisins. In another bowl, whisk the buttermilk and eggs together; lightly beat the buttermilk mixture into the flour mixture. Place the dough into the prepared cake pan.

Bake in the preheated oven until the bread has risen and the top is golden brown, 45 minutes to 1 hour. A knife inserted into the center of the bread should come out clean. Cool the bread in the pan on a wire rack for 10 minutes before removing. Serve warm.

review.reviewBody: While it was a decent bread on its own merit, it tasted nothing like a proper Irish Soda Bread. I was very disappointed, as was my dinner guest, an Irish gentleman, who ate some to be polite, but left most on his plate.

This was the first time I made Irish Soda Bread. (Always bought it from a bakery or friends made it) I love soda bread and am picky about it. This recipe was delicious. It created a huge loaf that was prize worthy, moist, dense and tender. I put in Craisens (dry cranberries) and 2 teaspoons of caraway seeds, which added enough flavor without overtaking the delicate flavor of the bread. My family raved about the bread, saying; "It was the best soda bread they have ever had!"

I tried to half this recipe & it just didn't work. It resulted in more of a batter than a dough. I tried to add additional flour to it. It turned out okay, but I wasn't impressed with the taste at all. I did a plain loaf, without any raisins or currants. Thought about adding dates & walnuts, but didn't. The loaf looked nice. I baked it in a 9" round cake pan. Unfotunately, because of it being more like a batter, I wasn't able to "bless it", so maybe the angels didn't like that. Oh, well. At least my Colcannon came out halfway decent. Cancer sucks. It makes it so hard to get some things done. My elderly mother liked the bread. So, that was nice.
Best recipe so far...
Came out perfect and easy to make. Only thing I changed was craisins for the raisins because that's what I had. Will definitely make again.

This was the best ever Irish soda bread. The bread came out moist, not dried out like other recipes that I have tried, even after being reheated. Definitely delicious with a little Irish butter. My family loved it.

This is easy to make, light in texture, and tasty with or without the raisins. Paired it with the Stout Slow Cooker corned Beef and Veggies for this year's St. Patrick's Day dinner. Did not have a 9 inch cake pan, so used 10 inch--must cook for an hour at the recipe temp to be certain bread is fully cooked in the middle (which it was not, despite knife coming out clean after 45 minues). This bread could also be good with summer grillling as a side. Also found some diced cinnamon-sugar apples to try next time in place of raisins.

The taste was good but it ended up (ie. next day) it was quite dry. However, that may be my own fault. I may have added too much flour. I'm going to try again but will half the recipe because there was A LOT!

I did not change a thing and followed the recipe exactly. It turned out amazing and I got rave reviews from my family. This recipe is a keeper and will be used regularly, not just on St. Patrick's day. Thank you allrecipes!

We don't usually like Irish Soda Bread. But I felt we needed something else for the meal. So what the heck I gave this a try. I added one cup of sugar instead of 3/4. Anyhow, this is great bread. Light and fluffy not dence and heavy like most Irish Soda Breads. I saved this to make again next year. Thanks for sharing.

It was delicious, a huge hit, everyone at the party agreed ! I omitted the raisins, probably would have substituted with currents, but one guest did not like either. Highly recommend this recipe and I most likely will make this again ..!
I used 1/2 cranberries and 1/2 golden raisins. Moist and tasteful, I will make this again.
It’s the best soda bread I’ve ever made. It was perfect in the 9” pan, and I served it warm with our Irish dinner of Corned Beef and Cabbage.
This Irish Soda Bread is absolutely the best ever!
Wow! Everyone loved it. Make two.

I read several reviews before making it and opted to add a little vanilla and an additional 1/2 cup of sugar and I brushed melted butter on top when baked. I also decided to use 1/2 cake flour and 1/2 AP. Remember to use 2 T extra cake flour per cup for substitution. I agreed that it would overflow a 9 inch cake pan when I saw the batter so I used 2 pans. 8 inch pans would be ideal but I didn’t have. Put parchment round in the bottom and it came out with ease. I know that’s a lot of changes but thank you for getting me started in the right direction. Reminds me of a loaf sold at a bakery nearby that closed a few years ago. The line would be out the door.

Did not have good luck with this one.
I have been making a certain Irish soda bread recipe for years ,I thought I would try something new.
it went all over the oven, after using the recommended pan. Not sure what happened, but what a mess. Oven has to be cleaned now. Taste was ok, certainly not worth the mess at all.

This is a wonderful recipe! I made it as written except only adding 1 c. of raisins. Even remembered to set out the butter, eggs and buttermilk to reach room temp. It is a sticky dough and that's fine just pile it into a well greased pan. Baked up well in a 9" cake pan for 55 minutes. Excellent flavor just like Irish soda bread from a bakery. Reheat wedges in the oven for extra crispness then slather on the butter. Yum!

Made it on a hot and humid day. I got some liquid paste instead of dough. This was after withholding 1/4 cup of buttermilk and reducing from 3 eggs to 2 eggs. I believe portion in the recipe is problematic. I divided the paste into two batches for baking since others said it didn't cook through otherwise. Took 30 min and it was done. Got something resembled sweet muffin instead of soda bread. Very disappointing. If I make it again, I would look for a recipe with less eggs, less butter, fewer raisins, definitely less sugar.
This bread is lovely, and very easy to make. However, I wouldn't call it an Irish Soda Bread, as it tastes nothing like it, but is sweet and has more ingredients. Toasted it's great for breakfast.
My family love that great bread! Thank you!

This is by far the best Irish Soda recipe that I have found.
My family loves it; I even made a mini-round for my daughter that doesn't like raisins which turned out great!
It really was great! I tried 4 different recipes, and this was everyone's favorite!
It really was great! I tried 4 different recipes, and this was everyone's favorite!
This was absolutely amazing.

This was one of the easiest soda breads I've ever made! It wasn't too sweet/cakey (some I've made are more like babka) and it wasn't too dry/crumbly, either. It was just right! 

(I didn't have buttermilk, so I added a tbsp of white vinegar to whole milk, and it was fine...)
This was absolutely excellent as designed. Came out sweet and delicious.

Hubby said best ever! And he's Irish...
I used Golden raisins too.

Hubby said best ever! And he's Irish...
I used Golden raisins too.

I made some substitutions .....used 2 cups of sugar instead of 1.5, added 2 tablespoons of vanilla extract, used 2 cups of craisins instead of 1.5 cups of raisins, cooked it for 1.5 hours and finished it off with some powdered sugar. Came out great!

Raisins are plenty sweet, you don't need so much white sugar. I put in caraway seeds, because what's Irish soda bread without them? Also used half whole wheat flour. It was fairly brittle and crumbly.

This is an awesome tasting Irish Soda Bread. It is made better served warm with a generous pat of room temp Irish Butter. We made this in a 2.75 Quart enamel-coated high-end brand cast-iron dutch oven. We extended the bake time to 1 hr 15 minutes at 350 degrees Fahrenheit, turned the oven off then left inside the oven for an additional 15 minutes.
I’ve changed the raisins for craisins . A big hit!
Yum! Followed other reviews and added half a cup of sugar. Otherwise followed it to a tee (I did make my own buttermilk). It came out wonderfully.

I tried this for the first time today, and it smells incredible. I had a moment of panic when I realised I was missing the sour cream, but since so many other recipes call for butter, I subbed a cup of that instead for great results. Who doesn't like butter?!? Well, my hips maybe, but this was worth the extra mile of walking today! I'll make this again for sure.

I made no chances to this recipe. I never made Irish Soda bread and let me tell you this was delicious taste nice and brown on top raised unbelievable my husband was also impressed. I had friends over for dinner I made corn beef and cabbage and I serve this bread with dinner OMG they loved it moist the ladies want the recipe and of course I gave it to them. I will be making this recipe again for sure. Thank you for another wonderful recipe.
I used a 9” deep crock, but I had to bake it almost two hours. It turned out fantastic and we had it for St. Patrick’s Day Dinner!
It dries out quickly as they said, but I liked the flavour and toasted lightly it’s just great! I will make again, I think caraway seeds would be great.
I cooked 55 minutes at 360 and it turned out perfect!
Wonderful
I added a tablespoon of honey, some walnuts and baked for 45 minutes. It had cakey texture but it was really delicious. Definitely would make again.
it taste so good :)

I made this for the first time (March 2019). I only made 1/2 recipe, used 3/4 cup white sugar; 2 eggs; baked in 9 1/2 inch round pyrex dish for only 35 minutes. It was delicious. We will definitely make this recipe again. Don't over bake - especially in glass cookware.

I don't know anything about soda bread authenticity, but this tasted great. I left the caraway seeds out for one loaf and put half in for another. Without was great on its own and with butter - and with was PERFECT with an Irish beef stew we made.
added 1 tbsp. of caraway seeds

As the recipe says, this soda bread is more like a moist cake due to more sugar and butter than I would normally use, but it is excellent. It won't replace my less sweet and less dense Irish soda bread, but is a delight with tea, and a favorite breakfast in our home.

I can't say if this is "authentic" or not, nothing Irish about my family! I can say it could not be easier or more delicious. I followed the recipe exactly except I had to make my own buttermilk using milk and white wine vinegar. Baked in a cast iron skillet. Awesome, easy and I will make it again and again!
Update: I went to make this and realized I didn't have any milk or buttermilk. Subbed fat free Greek yogurt for buttermilk. It worked great, in fact it might be even better!
Very good bread I would substitute cranberries for next time

Excellent soda bread! I followed the recipe and it turned out perfect. Only change was I used 1/2 raisins and 1/2 currants. The bread has a good sweetness, if served with some good irish butter, but if I was using jam on it, I would reduce the sugar. It is important to let the bread cool before cutting into it. It was nice and moist and cross on the outside.

My grandsons absolutely loved it!! Had another piece of bread instead of dessert. 
Kathie, 
Bellevue , NE
Cut the sugar down a 1/4 cup and only used 1 cup raisins.

I followed this recipe as written. It is very good. It was a little dry for me so I’m wondering if maybe I overlooked it. I’ve never tasted irish soda bread before and I’ll definitely make it again. My family really liked it too.
Outstanding recipe! Delicious. Will definitely make it again. A real favorite.
I made it just as the recipe directed but the raisins I had were a little old so I soaked them in Captain Morgan. I think the buttermilk made all the difference .

I made this for St. Patrick's Day and will never purchase store bought soda bread again!

I like caraway seeds in my soda bread so I added 2 tablespoons to this recipe and lessened the raisins a bit. 

I also baked it on a pizza stone because after leaving the dough to rise for about 10 min (recipe here does not state this), it nearly doubled in size. I couldn't imagine fitting this into a 9in cake pan to begin with anyway.
Definitely make again bread. My son-in-law loved it. Next time will do half plain and half with raisins for my daughter. It was so easy to make and bake. Had to cook a little longer to do the center.
I used a mix of golden raisins and currents. The dough was very wet and tough to handle, requiring a lot of additional flour. But delicious! I liked how it turned out baked in a cake pan.

This is my first review, and this recipe is amazing! Moist, flavorful, and a big hit at my house for picky eaters. Would 100% recommend trying this. Only change I made was from another review. Sprinkled a small bit of sugar on top before baking. It will be a staple in our house!

Baked for an hour in a 9" high-sided cake pan, it tested as done, however, when I tried to take it out of the pan after 10 minutes cool down time, it was still raw. Made a huge mess! Should have baked it for two hours.

I doubled the recipe and baked in mini-spring form pans. Came out fantastic. The only change was for the double recipe - I used one box of Zante Currants and coated them with a little of the flour mixture before doing anything else. This soda bread is great for dessert, breakfast, or snacking. However, if you want to eat a soda bread with your corned beef and cabbage - try a more savory recipe with caraway seeds in it. Thanks for this fantastic recipe!

This is the exact recipe I received long ago.... to up the protein I sub the buttermilk with 1 cup Greek yogurt and 1/2 cup mik. I bake at 350 for 50 min in a well greased 9” Pan and be it is perfect every time!

Made a couple of changes. I soaked my raisins in hot water to plump them up. I whisked the eggs and buttermilk in the mixer using the whisk attachment. Changed to the dough hook, then added the flour mixture and raisins alternatively a little at a time. Mixed on low until nicely combined. Baked it in a 9X4 loaf pan for 45mins and it was still gooey in the centre,baked for 15 mins. longer. Turned out nice. I give it a 4.5! Not perfect but almost.
Delish! Made it with Crasins instead of rasins.
Better than my Gran's. I have made it twice and it just disappears.

This was the best soda bread recipe!! It was very easy and very rich in taste. For carraway lovers , this can be added too! Everyone loved it and said it was the best tasting soda bread they ever have tasted.
This recipe was wonderful. Perfect with Corned Beef and Cabbage. I did add a little grated orange rind to recipe, but other than that I wouldn't change anything else. Delicious.
I made this today, exactly as written. It was nice and moist and absolutely delicious!
Oh my! Such a beautiful presentation. Easy recipe and it is yummy.

This is my favorite Irish Soda Bread (though to be honest, my mom makes it, not me). It's more moist than most other soda breads I've had, with the right amount of sweetness. We jokingly call it Wealthy Irish Soda Bread because of the eggs and raisins.

This recipe is amazingly easy. It came out moist and quite delicious. Not too sweet as the raisins /currants give it enough. Definitely going to throw some of this together for my next potluck at work :)

I just made this and it tastes really great - very easy to make as well. My only warning - I used a 9 inch cake pan as noted in the recipe - definitely not big enough, luckily I put the pan on a cookie sheet, or this would have been all over the oven. Will make again, next time in a bigger pan, maybe a tube/bundt pan would probably be perfect. Thanks for the recipe.

I made this recipe twice now. Didn't bake evenly in a 9" pie pan either time. Went over sides first time. Second time, used a deeper pan, but bread ended up very dry because of its density and time necessary to bake through. Took two different breads to work. The other recipe went very quickly while this one still has some sitting in break room.

Oh...MG! This soda bread was amazing! WAS because I brought it to a pre St. Paddy's Day party and bu-bye. All gone. I, too, added a little vanilla and an extra 1/2 cup sugar as the other reviews suggested. I ground cinnamon and sugar (comes combined in a grinder at Trader Joe's) on top and baked in 2-9" round pans. Seriously, the best soda bread I've ever had. Not at all like the kind I remember growing up (DRY.) This was moist with just the right amount of sweet.

I hope everyone enjoys this recipe! This is my mom's recipe and it's pretty hard to beat! This is an authentic Irish-American recipe - that's what we are! My mom passed away in 2013 but she would be so happy knowing her wonderful recipe is being shared :) Can't wait to make this year, enjoy everyone! After you make it, try it lightly toasted smeared with some Irish butter... it's amazing.

Just made this for St. Patrick's Day. Followed suggestions and added 1/2 cup sugar and 1 teaspoon vanilla extract. Put batter in 2 9-inch cake pans. When they were done baking poured some melted butter on top and sprinkled on some green sugar. Turned out amazing!! Everyone loved it. Made 8 loaves and gave them out for gifts.
Followed the recipe, except for tossing in some vanilla extract, used a 9" cake pan, 2 " high, and sprinkled a little sugar on top before baking. Loverly !

Not often does anyone ask for the recipe of something I serve. When my friend, the professional baker asked for it, I was thrilled. Add an extra 1/2 cup of sugar (stumbled on this by accident, but it was better for it.)

This recipe is the real deal as far as Irish Soda Bread is concerned, both my parent are from Ireland and while their recipes have a tiny bit of variance,(much like Italian families meatball recipes do) the end result is authentic and fantastic!

This bread was wonderful...I added the dried fruit, and a bit of dark chocolate...HMmmm. This will become a "quick go-to recipe" for when you just want something quick, easy and wonderfully moist and delicious.

I just got this recipe today and decided to try it immediately. It was a breeze to mix up, didn't even need a mixer. I followed the recipe and directions exactly, except I didn't have a 9-inch round cake pan. Instead I used a round casserole dish the same size. The finished product is beautiful, rounded and golden brown. Once it cooled, I sliced it and it slices beautifully too. However the texture is not like any soda bread I've ever had before. It's more like a muffin or quick bread. It's a little bit sweet too. I think it would be marvelous with peanut butter on it and I will definitely make it again. I just won't plan to serve sandwiches on it. It would be lovely toasted with butter & jam with hot tea also!
I thought this came out great. It was nice and moust with a crumbly outer crust.

I baked this today, St. Patrick's Day, and absolutely loved it. Using the All Recipes calculator, I halved the recipe and baked it in an 8" iron skillet. I don't like the commercial soda breads that are dry and almost stale in texture. This was dense, but moist and it rose beautifully. I sprinkled cinnamon sugar on the top so it smelled as good as it looked.

Good Irish soda bread. I used white whole wheat flour and sugar in the raw in the same measurements as in the original recipe. I did not put the dough in a round pan based on the comments from another rater who said it is too much dough for the pan. I baked mine on a cookie sheet and it worked well. I will definitely be making this again.

this bread hit some what the middle of the road for us. While I thought it was 3, my son gave it a 3. My oldest gave it a 4, while my middle daughter and my hubby gave it a 5. I'd never made this kind of bread. The recipe was very easy. It wasn't sweet, but was like a light biscuit bread. The raisins made it sweet. Can't say it was the best bread but can't say it was the worst either. But what I can say is that it was okay, but this batch needs to be divided into 2. The reason I say that is because It's so dense, that the bottom center never got completely baked even after it was in the oven an hour and 15 minutes. While it looked pretty, it was to thick. 2 smaller round loaves would have been better for the baking process. But I think in my own preference. To improve this better for my taste. Add just a hint of cinnamon to it. But it's an okay bread.
Great recipe...not like a traditional Irish soda bread...this is really like a cake. I added a touch of vanilla. It's delicious!

I just made this last night and it was GREAT. Easy to make. I had to add a little more flour because the consistency was too stick. Family thought it wasn't sweet enough so next time I am adding a little more sugar to the recipe.
